instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No damage not turning on
threads.message:
Another one that just died on it's own.

No visible liquid or any other damage. Reported by the user that just died.

The fan will spin for 5-6 seconds and all rails are present
No short found on any big caps or coils

Once the fan stops all the pch signals are there, s5 pwrgd is there but no <SIGNAL>SUS_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No damage not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No damage not turning on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PLT_REST_L</SIGNAL> goes to stable 3.3V for the time the board is on 5-6 seconds

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No damage not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No damage not turning on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST</SIGNAL>-PWRGD is at stable 1V and <SIGNAL>VR_READY</SIGNAL> at 1.05V steady

The CPU also gets hot in these 5 seconds.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No damage not turning on
threads.message:
Try starting in SMC bypass mode.
If still the same, try known good BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No damage not turning on
threads.message:
I forgot to mention that I already tried SMC bypass and there was no difference
I tried a known good efi chip just to see if there is any difference but it's the same behaviour.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No damage not turning on
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No damage not turning on
threads.message: With LCD connected nothing for the first few seconds and then jumps to about 20 mV, it's very low for very short not sure if i can call that a pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No damage not turning on
threads.message: Did you note the fan starting with full speed in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No damage not turning on
threads.message: Yes, the fan is starting at full speed in SMC bypass and normal speed in normal mode.
